sections.title: Description
sections.raw_content: The delay statement is used to cause the program to pause for a given time. The time duration is in milliseconds.
sections.text_content: The delay statement is used to cause the program to pause for a given time. The time duration is in milliseconds.
sections.mdown_content: The **delay** statement is used to cause the program to pause for a given time. The time duration is in milliseconds.

sections.title: Example
code:
for i : 1 .. 10
            put i
            delay (1000)    % Pause for 1 second
        end for
sections.raw_content: This program prints the integers 1 to 10 with a second delay between each.
sections.text_content: This program prints the integers 1 to 10 with a second delay between each.
sections.mdown_content: This program prints the integers 1 to 10 with a second delay between each.

sections.title: Details
sections.raw_content: On Apple Macintoshes, the hardware resolution of duration is in units of 17 milliseconds (1/60th of a second). For example, delay(500) will delay the program by about half a second, but may be off by as much as 17 milliseconds.
sections.text_content: On Apple Macintoshes, the hardware resolution of duration is in units of 17 milliseconds (1/60th of a second). For example, delay(500) will delay the program by about half a second, but may be off by as much as 17 milliseconds.
sections.mdown_content: On Apple Macintoshes, the hardware resolution of duration is in units of 17 milliseconds (1/60th of a second). For example, **delay**(500) will delay the program by about half a second, but may be off by as much as 17 milliseconds.
